case_id: Sonu v. State & Ors. (Delhi High Court, CRL.M.C. 358/2024, Decided on 17.01.2024)
facts: Petition filed by Sonu (Petitioner) under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, 1973 (CrPC) seeking quashing of FIR No. 0036/2022.
The FIR was registered on 12.01.2022 at Police Station Dwarka Sector-23, New Delhi.
The FIR was registered at the instance of Respondent No. 2 (wife of the Petitioner) for offences under Sections 498A, 406, and 34 of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
The FIR stemmed from matrimonial disputes between the Petitioner and Respondent No. 2.
During the pendency of proceedings, the parties resolved their disputes amicably.
A settlement agreement was reached between the parties before the Mediation Centre, Saket Courts, New Delhi, recorded in a report dated 06.12.2023.
As per the settlement, a total sum of Rs. 4,00,000 was agreed to be paid by the Petitioner to Respondent No. 2 as full and final settlement.
The first installment of Rs. 2,00,000 was paid by the Petitioner to Respondent No. 2.
The parties obtained a decree of divorce by mutual consent under Section 13B(2) of the Hindu Marriage Act, 1955, from the Family Court, Saket Courts, New Delhi, on 10.01.2024.
Both Petitioner and Respondent No. 2 appeared before the High Court (identified by the Investigating Officer) and affirmed the settlement.
Respondent No. 2 stated before the High Court that she entered into the settlement voluntarily, without any fear, force, or coercion, and had no objection to the quashing of the FIR.
The Learned Additional Public Prosecutor (APP) for the State (Respondent No. 1) also stated no objection to the quashing of the FIR based on the settlement.
ipc_sections: Section 34 (Acts done by several persons in furtherance of common intention)
Section 406 (Punishment for criminal breach of trust)
Section 498A (Husband or relative of husband of a woman subjecting her to cruelty)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Prima facie case based on original FIR: The Petitioner (husband), possibly acting with others (Sec 34), subjected Respondent No. 2 (wife) to cruelty as defined under Section 498A IPC.
precedents: Arnesh Kumar v. State of Bihar (2014) 8 SCC 273 (Context of 498A arrests and misuse)
Preeti Gupta v. State of Jharkhand (2010) 7 SCC 667 (Need for specific allegations against relatives)
Rupali Devi v. State of Uttar Pradesh (2019) 5 SCC 384 (Jurisdiction for 498A includes place where wife takes shelter)
elements: Subjection to cruelty (mental/physical harassment, potentially linked to dowry demands)
Cruelty inflicted by husband or his relatives

counter_arguments.loophole: Allegations may be general and omnibus, lacking specific incidents, dates, or roles attributed to each accused, potentially indicating misuse.
supporting_precedents: Kans Raj v. State of Punjab (2000) 5 SCC 207 (Warns against vague allegations roping in entire family)
Neelu Chopra v. Bharti (2009) 10 SCC 184 (Specific allegations required against each accused)
Geeta Mehrotra v. State of U.P. (2012) 10 SCC 741 (Quashing appropriate if allegations are vague)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Prima facie case based on original FIR: The Petitioner (husband), possibly with others (Sec 34), committed criminal breach of trust concerning Respondent No. 2's stridhan or other entrusted property.
precedents: Rashmi Kumar v. Mahesh Kumar Bhada (1997) 2 SCC 397 (Stridhan entrustment to husband/in-laws creates a trust)
Pratibha Rani v. Suraj Kumar (1985) 2 SCC 370 (Stridhan is wife's absolute property; non-return can be breach of trust)
State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal 1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (FIR can be quashed if allegations don't constitute an offence)
elements: Entrustment of property (stridhan) or dominion over it
Dishonest misappropriation, conversion, use, or disposal of property
Violation of legal contract or direction regarding discharge of trust

counter_arguments.loophole: Lack of specific details regarding entrusted items, date of entrustment, or evidence of dishonest intent; dispute might be civil in nature.
supporting_precedents: Velji Raghavji Patel v. State of Maharashtra AIR 1965 SC 1433 (Proof of entrustment is essential for Sec 405/406)
Onkar Nath Mishra v. State (NCT of Delhi) (2008) 2 SCC 561 (Mere dispute over property doesn't automatically imply criminal breach of trust)
S.W. Palanitkar v. State of Bihar (2002) 1 SCC 241 (Distinction between breach of contract and criminal breach of trust)

defense_arguments.argument: The offences (498A, 406 IPC) arise from a matrimonial dispute, primarily private in nature, suitable for quashing post-settlement under inherent powers (Sec 482 CrPC).
edge_cases: Ensuring offences are not 'heinous' or impacting 'society at large' (e.g., excluding offences like murder, rape, dacoity, economic fraud, terrorism). This case involves standard matrimonial sections generally considered private.
Verification of voluntariness of the settlement.
precedents: Gian Singh v. State of Punjab (2012) 10 SCC 303 (Landmark case establishing power to quash in private disputes based on settlement)
B.S. Joshi v. State of Haryana (2003) 4 SCC 675 (Specifically allowed quashing of 498A/406 cases post-settlement for matrimonial harmony)
Narinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2014) 6 SCC 466 (Guidelines for quashing based on settlement, considering nature of offence)

defense_arguments.argument: Parties have voluntarily settled all disputes via mediation, evidenced by a formal agreement and actions taken thereon (payment, mutual divorce), making continued prosecution futile.
edge_cases: Partial non-compliance with settlement terms (though here, significant steps like payment and divorce were completed).
Possibility of settlement being under duress (countered by complainant's statement in court).
precedents: Jitendra Raghuvanshi v. Babita Raghuvanshi (2013) 4 SCC 58 (Reaffirmed quashing power in settled matrimonial cases to secure ends of justice)
State of M.P. v. Laxmi Narayan (2019) 5 SCC 688 (Consolidated guidelines; quashing possible even for non-compoundable offences if dispute is private and settlement genuine)
Parbatbhai Aahir v. State of Gujarat (2017) 9 SCC 641 (Summarized principles guiding Sec 482 CrPC power in settlement cases)

defense_arguments.argument: Continuing criminal proceedings after compromise and mutual divorce would be an abuse of the legal process and would not serve the ends of justice.
edge_cases: State's interest in prosecution vs. parties' interest in resolution.
Precedent value if serious allegations are quashed routinely (mitigated by court's assessment of case facts).
precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal 1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (Lists categories where High Court can exercise Sec 482 powers, including abuse of process)
Gian Singh v. State of Punjab (2012) 10 SCC 303 (Ends of justice often better served by quashing in settled private disputes)
Narinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2014) 6 SCC 466 (Futility of trial post-settlement is a key consideration)

judgment.outcome: Petition allowed. FIR No. 0036/2022 registered under Sections 498A/406/34 IPC at PS Dwarka Sector-23, New Delhi, and all consequential proceedings emanating therefrom were quashed.
reasoning: The dispute originated from matrimonial discord, primarily constituting a private matter between the Petitioner and Respondent No. 2.
The parties voluntarily settled their disputes through mediation on 06.12.2023.
Significant terms of the settlement, including payment of Rs. 2,00,000 (out of Rs. 4,00,000) and obtaining mutual divorce on 10.01.2024, were complied with.
Respondent No. 2 personally appeared in court, confirmed the voluntary nature of the settlement, and expressed no objection to the quashing.
The State, through the Learned APP, did not object to the quashing.
Considering the nature of the offences and the voluntary settlement leading to divorce, the chances of conviction are remote and negligible.
Continuing the proceedings would be an exercise in futility and an abuse of the process of the court.
Quashing the FIR serves the ends of justice by allowing the parties to move forward based on their amicable resolution.
The court relied upon the legal principles established by the Supreme Court regarding quashing of FIRs based on settlement in matrimonial cases.

Narinder Singh v. State of Punjab (2014) 6 SCC 466
